isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9200, 9300, 9400 Models Built After January 1, 1995 - ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING CUMMINS M11 & N14 ELECTRONIC ENGINE SYSTEM

svcsection.title: ELECTRICAL TROUBLESHOOTING CUMMINS M11 & N14 ELECTRONIC ENGINE SYSTEM

lev1.para: This section covers International installed components and circuits that directly interact with the Cummins M11 and N14 CELECT Electronic Engine Controls. CELECT is the name of the Cummins' heavy duty engines with a full authority fuel control injection system.

item.para: Provides operation descriptions of International installed components and circuits that work with the Cummins Electronic Engine Controls.
Provides Troubleshooting Charts for those circuits and components installed by International.
Provides locations for International installed circuits.

lev1.para: The Cummins Electronic Troubleshooting Manuals should be used to diagnose the engine control system, then use the step-by-step troubleshooting charts included in DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING.
Refer to the circuit diagram in CTS-5119S for the following discussion.
Cummins publications can be ordered from local Cummins Distributors or:
Cummins Engine Co., Inc. Publishing Services CMC 40924 Box 3005 Columbus, IN 47202-3005

lev1.title: Overview
lev1.para: The M11/N14 controllers provide many engine/vehicle functions including:
Refer to the Cummins Engine Manual furnished with the vehicle for additional feature information.

Since each engine control system is electronically programmable to individual owner specifications, the operating parameters will vary from vehicle to vehicle. These parameters include: maximum cruise speed, shift schedules, governor type (automotive type or variable speed), idle RPM, full engine shutdown as part of the engine protection system, and many others.

The electronic control module (ECM) is the control center of the CELECT system. The ECM receives input from Cummins and International sensors and switches, processes the information, then uses electrical signals to control engine and vehicle functions.
The ECM receives inputs from International installed components including:
The ECM receives information from the sensors and switches and sends signals to the injectors, fuel shutoff valve, and engine brake relay.

lev3.title: Standard Engine Protection System
lev3.para: CELECT engines are equipped with an engine protection system as a standard feature. This feature includes the "yellow" Service/Check Engine Light (referred to in Cummins literature as an Engine Protection Light). This system monitors important engine parameters and logs diagnostic faults when an over-or under-normal operating range condition occurs. The engine protection also derates engine torque and engine speed when certain engine fluid parameters pass a limit point.
The ECM also logs the time of the occurrence and other relevant information. This data can be read using an Electronic Service Tool (EST).

The Service/Check Engine Light will turn ON at the occurrence then begin blinking after a period of time. This blinking operation is to warn the driver that the condition has been active for a period of time or else the pressure or temperature condition has become worse. The Engine Protection system monitors:
** Cummins Installed
* International Installed
With the key ON and engine OFF and with the Diagnostic switch OFF, the Service/ Check Engine Light will come ON for two seconds and then turn OFF as a system test.

lev3.title: CELECT Engine Protection Shutdown
lev3.para: This system is customer selectable and can be enabled using Electronic Service Tools (EST). This system will shut down the engine whenever monitored parameters fall outside the operating range.

The engine protection shutdown is triggered when the Service/Check Engine Light starts flashing for the current engine protection/warning derate. Once triggered, the engine will shut down after 30 seconds.
During the 30-second warning period, the standard torque and speed derates will occur.

The engine can be restarted by cycling the key switch. After the engine is restarted, it will be limited to the maximum torque and/or speed derate levels of the out-of-range parameter, if the engine protection fault is still active.
If an engine protection fault goes inactive during the 30 second shutdown warning period, the engine will return to normal operation and will not shut down.
With the key ON and engine OFF and with the Diagnostic switch OFF, the Service/ Check Engine Light will come ON for two seconds and then turn OFF as a system test.

lev2.title: On-Board Diagnostics
lev2.para: The CELECT system has a built-in diagnostic capability which alerts the driver of a system problem while the engine is running.

The "yellow" Engine Warning Light (not to be confused with the Service/Check Engine Light) will turn ON to warn the driver of an active component or system fault. While it indicates a failure has happened, the vehicle can be operated safely. The vehicle should be serviced to solve the problem, but the situation is not considered an emergency.
A lighted "red" Stop Engine Light indicates a major CELECT system problem and the vehicle should be stopped and engine shutdown as soon as is safely possible.
With the key ON and engine OFF and with the Diagnostic switch OFF, the indicator lights will come ON for two seconds and then turn OFF as a system test.
Refer to DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING for additional diagnostic information.

lev2.title: Engine Electronic Control Module (ECM)
lev2.para: The ECM is connected to the International electrical system at three points (or four points with Antilock Brakes installed).

item.para: International engine harness 28-way ECM connector (252) connects to ECM port B. This connector links International sensors and switches and the diagnostic connector to the ECM.

International 9-way connector (251) connects to the Cummins Sensor Harness. This connector links the International installed engine brake components, low coolant switch, fan controls and switched voltage to the ECM.

The International ECM power connector (225) connects to the Cummins Actuator harness. This connector supplies the unswitched power to the ECM and provides an ECM ground circuit to the engine ground stud.

Additionally, with ABS/Traction control systems, the International 2-way J1922 Data Link connector (411) connects to the Cummins Sensor Harness located near the front of the ECM. J1922 connector (403) connects to the ABS system. Refer to CTS-5119S Circuit Diagram Book.

lev3.title: Unswitched Battery Feed And Ground
lev3.para: The ECM receives battery power at all times through International Power Connector (225). ECM battery power is supplied at all times from the cranking motor solenoid B+ terminal. Circuits 97 and 97A deliver power on the International harness through the ECM Power Connector (225) and the Cummins harness to the ECM. The Cummins harness has a 10A inline fuse in each circuit.

The ECM ground is through the Cummins harness, ECM Power Harness Connector (225) and circuit 97-G to the engine ground stud. The engine ground stud is connected to the cranking motor ground stud, frame rail and negative battery terminal.

lev3.title: Switched Battery Power To ECM
lev3.para: Turning the key ON applies ignition power from 5A fuse F9-B to 9-way ECM connector (251) terminal D. Refer to Section 1.0 starting on page 3 for ignition voltage source to ignition adapter (494).

lev3.title: Service/Check Engine Light
lev3.para: The Service/Check Engine Light is part of the Engine Protection system (refer to Engine Protection Systems).

The Service/Check Engine Light is located in the left gauge cluster. The cluster receives ignition voltage (key ON) at connector (423) terminal 3, circuit 28A. Circuit 28A receives ignition power from 10A fuse F4-A. Refer to Power Distribution And Ground System on page 4 for ignition voltage source to fuse F4-A.
The ground side of Service/Check Engine Light is connected through connector (423) terminal 13, by circuit 97AZ to ECM connector (252) terminal 1.

The Service/Check Engine Light is turned ON and OFF by the ECM opening or closing a ground switch in response to engine conditions. Note that with the key ON and engine OFF and diagnostic switch OFF, the light comes ON for two seconds and then goes OFF as a system test.

lev3.title: "Yellow" Engine Warning Light
lev3.para: The Engine Warning Light is part of the On-Board Diagnostics system (refer to On-Board Diagnosticsor DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING).

The Engine Warning light is located in the left gauge cluster. The cluster receives ignition voltage (key ON) at connector (423) terminal 12, circuit 28D. Circuit 28D receives ignition power from 10A fuse F4-A. Refer to POWER DISTRIBUTION AND GROUND SYSTEM section for ignition voltage source to fuse F4-A.
The Engine Warning light is connected through connector (423) terminal 10 by circuit 97AT to ECM connector (252) terminal 25.

The Engine Warning light is turned ON and OFF by the ECM opening or closing a ground switch in response to engine conditions. Note that with the key ON and engine OFF and diagnostic switch OFF, the light comes ON for two seconds and then goes OFF as a system test.

lev3.title: Red Stop Engine Light
lev3.para: The Red Engine Stop light is part of the On-Board Diagnostics system (refer to On-Board Diagnosticsor DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING).

The Engine Warning light is located in the left gauge cluster. The cluster receives ignition voltage (key ON) at connector (423) terminal 12, circuit 28D. Circuit 28A receives power from 10A fuse F4-A. Refer to 1.0 on page 3 for ignition voltage source to fuse F4-A.
The Engine Stop light is connected through connector (423) terminal 11, by circuit 97AP to ECM connector (252) terminal 16.

The Engine Stop light is turned ON and OFF by the ECM opening or closing a ground switch in response to engine conditions. Note that with the key ON and engine OFF and diagnostic switch OFF, the light comes ON for two seconds and then goes OFF as a system test.

lev2.title: ATA Data Link Connector (137)
lev2.para: The 6-pin ATA Data Link connector (137) allows an Electronic Service Tool (EST) to communicate with the ECM. The data link carries serial data transmissions between the ECM and the electronic service tool and provides vehicle and engine speed infor- mation to the speedometer/tachometer unit.
The data link provides communication capabilities for:
Data Link connector (137) is located on the left instrument panel. Four of the six connector cavities have terminals. Those terminal/circuits are as follows:
Six-pin diagnostic connector (137) utilizes four circuits as follows:

item.para: Terminal A, circuit 98A(+), is the positive data link connection to Positive Data Link connector (514) terminal A. Data link connector (514) terminal B is connected by circuit 98(+) to ECM connector (252) terminal 27. Connector (514) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(+) to speedometer and tachometer connector (421). Connector (514) has a bus installed that electrically connects all the circuits in the connector together.

Terminal B, circuit 98C(-) is the negative data link connection to Negative Data Link connector (515) terminal A. Data link connector (515) terminal B is connected by circuit 98B(-) to ECM connector (252) terminal 8. Connector (515) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(-) to speedometer and tachometer connector (421). Connector (515) has a bus installed that electrically connects all the circuits in the connector together.
The positive and negative data link circuits are a twisted wire pair. Twisting the wires shields the wires from interference.
Terminal C, circuit 97DL, is 12V ignition feed from 5A fuse F9-C. Power is available with the key switch in the ON position to power the electronic service tool.
Terminal E, circuit 97-GR, is grounded through circuits 24-G/11-GT at panel light ground adapter (506), providing a ground for the electronic service tool.

lev2.title: Diagnostic ON/OFF Switch (241)
lev2.para: The Diagnostic ON/OFF switch is a lighted ON/OFF switch for the onboard diagnostics (also refer to DIAGNOSTICS AND TROUBLESHOOTING).

The diagnostic ON/OFF switch receives a 5V supply signal on circuit 97AN (5V). This signal comes from ECM connector (252) terminal 10 on circuit 97WZ (5V) through LS1 splice. Closing the switch applies the signal to circuit 97AM (signal return) which is connected to ECM connector (252) terminal 21. This tells the ECM that the diagnostic ON/OFF switch has been turned to the ON position.

lev2.title: Idle/Diagnostic Switch (243)
lev2.para: The lighted two-position, momentary Idle/Diagnostic switch is a dual function switch. The Idle/Diagnostic switch adjusts the low engine idle speed and is also used during onboard diagnostics (when the diagnostic switch is turned O) to move through the diagnostic fault code list.

The low engine idle speed (rpm) can be adjusted from the cab, using a two-position momentary, increment/decrement switch. This function permits adjusting idle speed up or down in units of 25 rpm by toggling the switch. Maximum idle speed is 800 rpm and minimum idle speed is 550 rpm. When the idle has been changed and the key turned OFF, the new setting is saved in memory. This feature is owner selected and can be turned OFF with a Compulink TMelectronic service tool.

A 5V supply signal from the ECM is present to switch terminal 2, on circuit 97AX(5V). Momentarily placing the switch in the increment position applies the signal on circuit 97AV (signal return) to ECM connector (252) terminal 14. This causes the engine idle rpm to increase 25 rpm.
Momentarily placing the switch in the decrement position applies the signal on circuit 97AU (signal return) to ECM connector (252) terminal 23. This causes the engine idle rpm to decrease 25 rpm.

lev2.title: Radiator Coolant Level Switch (249)
lev2.para: The Coolant Level Switch is a fluid-level-actuated switch that sends coolant LOW or coolant HIGH signal and provides a warning when coolant is being lost. It is mounted in the coolant surge tank.

The Coolant Level Switch is an electronic switch that operates on the electrostatic or capacitance principle, and cannot be tested with a multimeter. The probe extends into the coolant and produces a change in capacitance when coolant displaces air immediately surrounding the probe. This change is converted in the switch to an ON/OFF solid state switch closure indicating the absence or presence of coolant. The switch is electrically insulated providing a slick, non-fouling surface as well as good electrical characteristics to prevent current flow into the coolant.
The low coolant level switch connects to the engine harness at connector (249). Four circuits from connector (249) connect the low coolant switch to the ECM through the nine-way ECM connector (251).

lev3.title: Low Coolant Level Switch Operation
lev3.para: The Coolant Level Switch (249) receives a 5 VDC signal on circuit 34B(5V) at terminal C from connector (251) terminal A.

When the coolant level is above the probe, the switch sends a HIGH signal (3.5 volts minimum) from switch terminal D on circuit 34A to ECM connector (251) terminal C. At the same time the switch sends a LOW signal (0.5 volt maximum) from terminal A on circuit 34 to ECM connector (251) terminal B.

When the coolant level is below the probe, the switch sends a HIGH signal (3.5 volts minimum) from switch terminal A on circuit 34 to ECM connector (251) terminal B. At the same time the switch sends a LOW signal (0.5 volt maximum) from terminal D on circuit 34A to ECM connector (251) terminal C.
The Low Coolant Level switch is grounded from terminal B, circuit 34-G through ECM connector (308) terminal J.

note.para: The Low Coolant Level Switch should not be tested using a multimeter.

lev2.title: Fuel ShutOff Valve (Cummins Component)
lev2.para: A solenoid-controlled valve is mounted on the engine fuel pump that is controlled by the ECM. The valve opens when the vehicle key switch is turned ON, allowing fuel to flow to the injectors, and closes when the key switch is turned OFF. The valve is also closed by the ECM if the engine speed goes above 2730 rpm. Power to the valve will resume when the engine speed drops to approximately 2120 rpm.

lev2.title: Accelerator Pedal Assembly (242)
lev2.para: CELECT engines utilize an electronic accelerator pedal assembly that includes an integratedAccelerator Position Sensor (APS)/Idle Validation Switch (IVS). The accelerator pedal assembly is serviceable, to the extent that the APS/IVS switch is replaceable if defective, without replacing the whole assembly.

lev3.title: Accelerator Position Sensor (APS)
lev3.para: The APS is attached to the accelerator pedal. The APS acts like a potentiometer- movement of the pedal results in a variable signal being sent to the ECM that is proportional to pedal position.
A 5V signal from ECM connector (252) terminal 18 is applied on circuit 99A(5V) to APS/IVS connector (242) terminal C.

The variable wiper signal (varies with pedal position) from APS/IVS connector (242) terminal B returns on circuit 99, to ECM connector (252) terminal 11. This variable signal tells the ECM the position of the accelerator pedal.
The APS is grounded through APS/IVS connector (242) terminal A on circuit 99-G, to ECM connector (252) terminal 19.

note.para: Any time the accelerator pedal sensor (APS) is disconnected from the ECM with the key switch ON, the APS and ECM must be recalibrated (refer to paragraph 1.2.8.4 on page 7).

lev3.title: Idle Validation Switch (IVS)
lev3.para: The IVS is used to indicate when accelerator pedal IS IN the low idle position and when the pedal IS NOT IN the low idle position.
A 5 volt supply signal from ECM connector (252) terminal 10 is applied on circuit 99D(5V) to APS/IVS connector (242) terminal F.
With accelerator in the low idle position, the IVS sends a signal from APS/IVS connector (242) terminal E on circuit 99B to ECM connector (252) terminal 6.
When accelerator is not in idle position, the IVS sends a signal from APS/IVS connector (242) terminal D on circuit 99C to ECM connector (252) terminal 9.

lev3.title: APS/IVS Interaction
lev3.para: The ECM analyzes the signals received from the APS and IVS signals making certain that the signals fall within certain parameters. For example: if the IVS signal indicates that the accelerator pedal is in the IDLE position, the ECM expects to see an APS signal that indicates that no throttle is applied. If it does not see a logical response from both, a fault code may be logged. The APS/IVS timing cannot be checked using a multimeter.

lev3.title: Calibrating Accelerator To ECM
lev3.para: The signals between the ECM and the accelerator pedal are low voltage (5V) and very low current (microamps). Because of these low voltages and currents, they must be electrically calibrated to one another for proper engine response.

item.para: The ECM and accelerator pedal must be calibrated:
When the accelerator pedal is initially installed.
When an accelerator pedal is replaced.
When a new calibration is down-loaded to the ECM.
When the accelerator pedal wiring is disconnected either at the pedal or at connector (252) while the key switch is ON.

lev3.para: To recalibrate the ECM and the accelerator pedal- the key must be ON, then the accelerator pedal must be slowly and fully depressed from idle to full throttle and then released. The accelerator pedal should be depressed and released three times.

lev2.title: Speedometer/Tachometer Inputs
lev2.para: Refer to section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for additional speedometer and tachometer information.
The ECM receives and processes a signal from Engine Position sensor (Cummins component) to determine engine speedand receives a signal from the vehicle speed sensor to determine vehicle speed.
To calculate vehicle speed from the vehicle speed sensor signal, the ECM is programmed with certain vehicle parameters (refer to ECM PROGRAMMING).
The ECM provides a signal over the data link circuits that the vehicle speedometer and tachometer cluster microprocessor uses to drive the gauges.

lev3.title: Positive Data Link Circuit To Speedometer And Tachometer
lev3.para: Positive data link circuit 98(+) connects ECM connector (252) terminal 27 to Datalink Positive Connector (514) at terminal B. Datalink Positive Connector (514) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(+) to speedometer/tachometer connector (421). Datalink Positive Connector (514) terminal A is connected by circuit 98A(+) to the ATA Data Link connector (137) terminal A. Connector (514) has a bus installed that connects all the circuits in the connector together. ATA Data Link connector (137) can be used to access information on the data link using an electronic service tool.

lev3.title: Negative Data Link Circuit To Speedometer And Tachometer
lev3.para: Negative data link circuit 98B(-) connects ECM connector (252) terminal 8 to Datalink Negative Connector (515) at terminal B. Datalink Negative Connector (515) terminal C is connected by circuit 47/48(-) to speedometer/tachometer connector (421). Datalink Negative Connector (515) terminal A is connected by circuit 98C(-) to the ATA Data Link connector (137) terminal B. Connector (515) has a bus installed that connects all the circuits in the connector together. ATA Data Link connector (137) can be used to access information on the data link using an electronic service tool.

lev3.title: ECM Programming
lev3.para: The ECM is programmed with vehicle component information, so the signal to the speedometer and tachometer is compatible. That information includes the following:

item.para: Magnetic Pickup VSS - YES or NO.
Number of Transmission Tail Shaft Gear Teeth - International installed transmissions have 16 teeth on counter wheel, including Allison transmissions.
Tire revolutions per mile (456-640). Refer to Table 8.01 on page 235.
Top gear final drive ratio (0.5 to 1.0).

table.title: Radial/Bias Tire Revolutions Per Mile Table

lev3.para: If vehicle components are changed (different tire size, rear axle etc.) the ECM must be reprogrammed with the correct data.The speedometer/tachometer unit does not get reprogrammed. An authorized Cummins EST is required for the reprogramming. Refer to Cummins service literature for this procedure.

lev3.title: Vehicle Speed Sensor (VSS)(250)
lev3.para: The VSS (250) is located at the rear of the transmission. The sensor contains a permanent magnet which creates a field that is repeatedly broken by the rotating speedometer output gear in the transmission. The gear has 16 teeth.

As the gear breaks the field an alternating current (AC) is generated. These pulses are transmitted from sensor connector (250) through circuits 97AJ and 97AK to the ECM through ECM connector (252) at terminals 3 and 7.

lev2.title: Engine Brake System
lev2.para: The ECM shares control of the Engine Brake System with the vehicle driver and the Antilock Brake System (ABS) if the vehicle is so equipped. The driver enables the engine brake with the ON/OFF switch (434).

Using the engine brake selector switch (433), the driver can select two-, four-, or six-cylinder braking for the N14 engine or can select three- or six-cylinder braking with the M11 engine, according to driver preference and driving conditions.
The ECM will not allow operation of the engine brake if it senses any of the following conditions:

item.para: ABS system is modulating the brakes.

lev3.title: ABS/ECM Communication
lev3.para: If the vehicle is equipped with antilock brakes (ABS), the ABS controller communicates through the J1922 data link connector (411) with the ECM. Connector (403) connects to the ABS system. If the ABS system senses wheel lockup may occur, it will modulate the tractor brakes. This is communicated to the ECM, which would then turn OFF the engine brakes.
The ABS system is discussed in GROUP 04 - BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

lev3.title: Engine Brake ON/OFF Switch (434)
lev3.para: The engine brake ON/OFF switch is a 2-pole, single throw lighted switch. One pole receives ignition power from 15A fuse F9-D, and with the key switch in the ON position, sends 12V ignition power on circuit 24AH to the engine brake enable relay (144) common terminal, numbered 30 in the circuit diagram.

The other pole of the Engine Brake ON/OFF receives a 5V supply signal from ECM connector (252) terminal 10 on circuit 24R(5V). With the engine brake switch ON (switch closed), a 5V signal is sent on circuit 24AB through ECM connector (252) terminal 5 to the ECM. This signal tells the ECM that the engine brake switch is in the ON position.

lev3.title: Engine Brake Enable Relay (144)
lev3.para: The engine brake enable relay is energized by the ECM applying 12 volts from the 9-way interface connector (251) terminal F, on circuit 24AA to the relay terminal 86, as shown on the circuit diagram. The relay control coil is grounded from relay terminal 85, circuit 24-G/11-GT at panel light ground adapter (506). The ECM enables the engine brake system by energizing the relay, when all previously discussed conditions (Engine Brake System.)are correct.

When the engine brake ON/OFF switch is ON, 12V ignition power from 15A fuse F9-D is sent on circuit 24AH to terminal 30 of the engine brake relay (144). When the engine brake relay is energized by the ECM, the power at terminal 30 goes from relay terminal 87 on circuit 24AD to engine brake selector switch (433) terminal 2.

lev3.title: Engine Brake Selector Switch (433)
lev3.para: The engine brake selector switch receives power from the engine brake enable relay (144) on circuit 24AD. The engine brake selector switch sends the 12-volt ignition power through the 9-way interface connector (251) and through the Cummins engine harness to selected engine brake solenoids (installed by Cummins). The power does not go through the ECM.
Circuit 24AE from the engine brake selector switch delivers power to the front and rear engine brake solenoids with N14 engines and to the front solenoid with M11 engines.
Circuit 24AF from the engine brake selector switch delivers power to the center engine brake solenoid with N14 engines and to the rear solenoid with M11 engines.

lev3.title: Service Brake Switch (141)
lev3.para: The service brake switch (closed with brake pedal released) serves both the cruise control and engine brake system. It is an air actuated switch that is closed when the brakes are released . Applying the brakes opens the switch.

The service brake switch receives a 5V signal on circuit 97W(5V) from ECM connector (252) terminal 10. When the brakes are not applied, a 5V signal is applied through circuit 97AL to ECM connector (252) terminal 13. The service brake switch openswhen the brakes are applied and no signalis applied to ECM connector (252) terminal 13.

lev3.title: Clutch Switch
lev3.para: The clutch switch serves both the cruise and engine brake system. The switch is a normally open switch, adjusted to be closed when the clutch pedal is in the released position. The clutch switch pigtail connects to the cab harness at connector (294).
The clutch switch receives a 5V signal on circuit 97AF(5V) from ECM connector (252) terminal 10.

With the clutch pedal released, a 5V signal on circuit 97AH is applied to ECM connector (252) terminal 4. The clutch switch openswhen the pedal is depressed and no signalis applied to ECM connector (252) terminal 4.

lev3.title: Cruise Operation
lev3.para: The cruise control system has three modes: OFF, Standby and Active. The position of the ON/OFF switch turns cruise control OFF. The standby mode occurs when the driver switches the cruise control ON/OFF switch to the ON position. The driver can then achieve the active mode by toggling the Set/Resume switch after reaching the desired road speed.

Once the system is active, the driver can accelerate beyond the set speed by depressing the accelerator pedal. When the pedal is released, cruise control is reactivated when the vehicle speed reaches the previously set speed.

Cruise is deactivated, returning to the standby mode in several ways: the brake or clutch pedal is depressed, the engine speed (rpm) drops below 1000 rpm, the vehicle speed (mph) drops below 30 miles per hour.
The resume switch can be used to reactivate cruise at the previous set speed, or the set switch can be used to establish a new set speed.

While in the active mode, the coast feature is used to decrease vehicle speed and establish a new lower set speed. By holding select switch in the position, vehicle speed decreases until switch is released; the speed at release becomes the new set speed.

While in the active mode, the accelerate feature is used to increase the vehicle speed and establish a new higher set speed. By holding the select switch in the position, vehicle speed increases until the switch is released; the speed at release becomes the new set speed.
Refer to Service Brake Switch and Clutch Switch (above) for clutch and service brake switch operation.

lev3.title: PTO Governor
lev3.para: The optional power takeoff (PTO) is a type of governor which controls the engine at a constant customer-selectable engine speed (rpm) regardless of engine load.
The PTO governor mode is activated using the cruise control switches, but only when vehicle speed is less than six miles per hour.
The PTO mode is disabled by depressing the clutch or brake pedal. In the PTO mode the throttle pedal does not affect PTO operation, but does not disable the PTO.
PTO allows the operator to set and control the engine speed in the same way cruise control sets and controls vehicle speed.
To activate the PTO, position the cruise ON/OFF switch in the ON position, then toggling either the Set or Resume switch will move the PTO into the active mode.
Toggling the Set switch will cause engine to idle at a Cummins preprogrammed 850 rpm. This engine speed can be reprogrammed using an Electronic Service Tool (EST).
Toggling the Resume switch will cause the engine to idle at a second preprogrammed customer-selectable speed.
The Accel and Coast positions can be used to increase or decrease engine speed, but not higher than the preprogrammed customer selectable maximum PTO operation speed (must be less than 2500 rpm).

lev3.title: Cruise ON/OFF Switch (435)
lev3.para: The lighted cruise control ON/OFF switch receives a 5V signal on circuit 97AD(5V) from ECM connector (252) terminal 10. In the ON position, a 5V signal is sent from switch terminal 6, on circuit 97AE to ECM connector (252) terminal 2. This indicates to the ECM that the cruise control switch is in the ON position. In the OFF position, circuit 97AE has 0 volts, indicating to the ECM that the switch is OFF.

lev3.title: Cruise Set/Resume Switch (436)
lev3.para: The lighted cruise Set/Resume switch is a momentary switch. This switch receives a 5V signal from ECM connector (252) on circuit 97AC (5V) at terminal 2. The cruise selector switch sends a 5V signal from terminal 3 on circuit 97AB to ECM connector (252) terminal 12 while in the SET/ACCEL position. In the RESUME/COAST position, the switch sends a 5V signal from terminal 1 on circuit 97AA to ECM connector (252) terminal 22.

lev2.title: Idle Shutdown Feature
lev2.para: Idle shutdown is a customer selectable feature. It can be enabled using Electronic Service Tools. If enabled, this feature will automatically shut the engine OFF after a customer selected period of time. If road speed equals 0 mph and idle shutdown is enabled, then the shutdown timer will be started, even if the brake, clutch, or throttle pedal are depressed. If activity occurs in the brake, clutch, or throttle pedal, the idle shutdown timer will reset and restart.

If idle shutdown is activated for the PTO mode, the engine will shut down after the specified amount of time while in PTO. If the customer selected idle shutdown to be deactivated in the PTO mode, then the engine will not shut down while in PTO mode.
